Funny, during a recent remote interview, I was asked an unexpected question:

Interviewer: Final question -- what's your view on Israel? Specifically, its recent military operations in Gaza?

I have checked the company before applying, but did not realize their genocidal support for the terrorists, and later found out.

My answer was like: those who deny genocide in Palestine are nothing but a humanoid clown, a disgrace to the human race. No human can commit such a crime in human civilization.

Unsurprisingly, I received a rejection email shortly after—and I’m genuinely relieved.

For the record, and to any future hiring managers reading this: I will always speak out against genocide, racism, and hate crimes. This isn’t arrogance, it’s a fundamental moral responsibility.

Job hunting in 2025 be like:

Apply.
Wait.
Get ghosted.
Reapply to the same job because they reposted it again.
Still ghosted.
Attend 6 rounds of interviews.
Solve a business case.
Design a product roadmap.
Fix the company’s entire strategy.
Only to hear:
“We went ahead with another candidate.”
And my personal favorite:
“We’ll get back to you soon.”
(They never do.)

Dear companies,
We don’t want coffee at your fancy office.
We just want clarity.
A yes or a no.

Not an existential crisis.

To all job seekers reading this -
You’re not lazy.
You’re not unskilled.
You’re not the problem.

You’re just stuck in a broken system where “hiring pipeline” matters more than human dignity.

So no -
You’re not overreacting.
You’re just exhausted from proving your worth to people who never intended to hire.

'You lack experience.'

Funny how the people who say this
never give you a chance to gain it.

You want fresh minds.
But don’t want freshers.

You want innovation.
But only hire from a list of 5 companies.

You want hustle.
But don’t pay for overtime.

You want 'passionate' people.
But ghost them after 6 interview rounds.

Let me tell you something:

🔥 Talent isn’t always wrapped in a fancy title.
🔥 Hunger doesn’t come with a brand name.
🔥 And success doesn’t need your validation.

To everyone out there -
Keep learning. Keep building.
One 'no' closer to the 'yes' that changes everything.

The job was posted 47 days ago.
Then 22 days ago.
Then 3 days ago.
Same job.
Same JD.
Same company.

You applied all 3 times.
Still no response.
Still no update.
Still nothing.

Here’s the harsh truth:
Not every job posting is real.
Not every company is hiring.
Some are just:

🔹 Building a candidate pipeline
🔹 Faking 'growth' for funding rounds
🔹 Testing the talent market
🔹 Showing activity to the board
🔹 Reposting ghost jobs for visibility

Meanwhile, jobseekers are customizing resumes, preparing for rounds, getting their hopes up -
Just to be ghosted by something that never existed.

It’s not just frustrating.
It’s emotionally exhausting.
It’s mentally draining.

If you're a company doing this -
You’re not just wasting time.
You’re playing with people’s lives.

To everyone who’s applying, waiting, praying -
This isn’t your fault.
You’re not lacking.
You’re just stuck in a system that often values optics over ethics.

Speak up. Share this. Tag someone who needs to know this.

Because the only thing worse than not getting selected -
is realizing the job never existed to begin with.

Some of the smartest people I know are jobless right now.

Not because they’re lazy.
Not because they don’t have skills.
But because the system is broken.

– Companies post fake jobs.
– They reopen the same roles every month.
– Candidates solve 5-hour assignments and get ghosted.
– Referrals go nowhere.
– Rejections come in 2 minutes.
– Or never.

And yet we still say: *'Keep applying. Your time will come.'*

Maybe.
But maybe the problem isn't us.
Maybe it’s the way hiring works — with no empathy, no accountability, no respect.

If you’re tired, frustrated, burnt out — you’re not alone.
You’re not a failure. You’re just stuck in a system that was never built to be kind.

And I’m done pretending that’s normal.

Hi everyone, I need your help - this is urgent.

One of my closest friends is going through the toughest phase of his life.

His father is critically ill with multiple organ damage and is fighting for his life in the ICU.
The required treatment is costing them ₹26 lakhs, and they've exhausted all their savings.

💔 Imagine watching the person who raised you, who was your entire world… just slipping away because of money.

Please take a moment to read, donate or simply share this. Even a small contribution or a repost can create a ripple.

📌 Please, if you’re reading this:

Donate whatever little you can

Repost this to your network

Or just leave a comment so it reaches more eyes

'Why should I pay you this much?'
'You didn’t even ask for this kind of raise at your last job.'

I told the recruiter my expected salary.

He asked:
'What was your last salary?'
'And how much are you earning now?'

Then he said something that hit me:
'Why should I pay you this much - when you didn’t even ask for this kind of raise in your last job?'

Let that sink in.

I wasn’t being judged for my skills.
Not for the role.
Not for the value I bring.

I was being judged… for once being underpaid.

Here’s the truth:
I didn’t ask for more back then because I couldn’t.
Because I was trying to get out of a toxic place.
Because I needed a job - not a negotiation.

When someone didn't negotiate in the past, it could be because:

– They were desperate to escape a toxic job
– They didn’t have multiple offers
– They didn’t know how to negotiate
– They were choosing mental health over money
– They were just surviving

Don’t hold someone’s past struggle against their present worth.

People grow. People learn. People bounce back.
And if they now know what they’re worth - that should be celebrated, not questioned.

Let me ask you:
If someone came out of a toxic relationship, would you ask them,
'Why did you tolerate that before?'
No. Because that’s cruel.

Then why do it with careers?

Don’t punish candidates for surviving.

Pay them for the role.
Pay them for their talent.
Pay them for what they’re worth today - not for what they settled for yesterday.

So if someone finally dares to ask for what they’re worth -
And your response is to shame them for their past?

You’re not just being unfair.
You’re being part of the problem.

Stop asking about past salaries.
Start building a system that doesn’t punish people for struggling.

People don’t need your judgment.
They need your respect.

Some of the most successful people feel empty inside.

Some of the kindest souls have the simplest resumes.

Some people are silently fighting battles that would break most of us - but still show up with a smile.

Some who motivate others… cry themselves to sleep.

Some who lead teams… feel completely lost inside.

Some who are always there for others… have no one checking in on them.

Some who speak the loudest… are begging to be heard in silence.

Some who look like they’ve 'made it'… still don’t feel enough.

Some who post wins on LinkedIn… are secretly scared it could all fall apart.

Some who laugh the hardest… are just hiding the deepest pain.

Some who never complain… are carrying the heaviest burdens.

Some who keep going… aren’t 'strong,' they’re just out of options.

So please -
Be kind.
Be gentle.
Be human.

Because what we see on the surface is never the full story.

Nobody claps for you at 2 AM.

When you're overthinking every decision.
When you're re-reading that one email 7 times to make sure you sound 'professional.'
When you're trying to act normal in meetings after crying 5 minutes before.
When you're still trying - even when nobody’s watching.

LinkedIn celebrates results.
But this - the messy, invisible part - is what it really takes.

The inner battles.
The self-doubt.
The fear of being 'not enough.'

So if you’re in that quiet war right now…
Still showing up, still trying, still hoping -
This post is your applause.

You’re doing better than you think.
And even if no one sees it -
I do.
